thread.title: RS:X World Windsurfing Championships: Pierre Le Coq, Peina Chen retain lead
thread.title_full: RS:X World Windsurfing Championships: Pierre Le Coq, Peina Chen retain lead

author: muscatdaily@apexmedia.co.om (Muscat Daily News)
title: RS:X World Windsurfing Championships: Pierre Le Coq, Peina Chen retain lead
text:
Follow us on RS:X World Windsurfing Championships: Pierre Le Coq, Peina Chen retain lead Participants compete on the second day of the 2015 World Windsurfing Championships at the Musannah Sports City on Tuesday Muscat Daily staff writer October 21, 2015 
The sailing conditions changed and the windsurfers had to overcome light winds and tricky tactical conditions on the second day of the 2015 RS:X World Windsurfing Championships at the Musannah Sports City on Tuesday. 
However, after a challenging day of three races, the overnight leaders in the men's and women's fleet - Pierre Le Coq of France and Peina Chen of China - remained on top. 
It was a day when the winds never reached more than eight knots and forced the windsurfers to have a tiring and physical outing with skills playing a crucial role. 
French girl Charline Picon in action at the Musannah Sports City 
The men's fleet was the first to be flagged off and enjoyed some of the best breeze of the day. Although Le Coq managed to maintain his overall lead with a couple of wins on Tuesday to add to his already impressive scoreline, he didn’t have it all his own way in the 82-strong fleet. 
In the day's second race - the yellow fleet - Spain's Ivan Pastor edged Le Coq in the closing stages and notched up his first win of the week, while China's Zhichao Zhi, sailing in his first ever world championship, won in the blue fleet. 
At the end of the day's racing, Zhi had a scoreline of four, one, two to move up the rankings to second overall with a nett score of 12. Le Coq has a nett score of six to remain on top, while Pastor was third with a nett score of 13. 
Zhi said, “This is the first time I have sailed abroad and it's my debut in a world championship. I am delighted to be here and I am really happy to be doing so well. I think the reason I am fast in these conditions is because I am light. The aim now is to continue to do well by sailing normally without taking too much pressure. I am really keen to learn from the other guys and to keep improving.” 
Zhichao Zhi of China competes in the blue fleet on Tuesday 
Overall leader Le Coq said, “Having three races in these conditions is very hard for us. It's very challenging to be in front and to be consistent, so I am really happy.” 
In the women’s fleet, 26 year old Peina retained her overall lead, but said she found it extremely tough on Tuesday. 
A penalty turn in the first race of the day was not the best start, but Peina managed a runner-up and a third-place finish in the next two races to total a nett of eight and stay ahead of the rest. 
Charline impresses 
One of the most notable performances came from French girl Charline Picon. A winner at the ISAF Sailing World Championships in Santander, Spain last year, she came up with a stunning performance. 
In the closing stages of the first race, she outplayed leader Zofia Noceti-Klepacka of Poland in the final stretch to snatch a win. She then went on to score another first place and a second, climbing to overall second with a nett score of ten. 
A delighted Charline said, “I had a very good day, but it is tough here. The light winds are physically demanding. As it is an Olympic qualifier, it is extremely competitive. Peina is in very good shape. From here on, it will be in more tough because I will be racing against only the best girls in the gold fleet and every point will be important.” 
Poland's Malgorzata Bialecka, who won the concluding blue fleet race of the day, retained her third place overall with a nett of 11. 
The windsurfers will take a break from action on Wednesday before returning to the waters on Thursday. 
The men and women’s fleets will be split into gold and silver fleets, according to overall rankings from the first two days (six races). The final round of races and the medal races will take place on Saturday. Similar content
